Our # XM5910B

NO NYC. This listing is for THREE magazines, hit Buy It and you’re buying 3, not 1. Winning buyer can take any number of extras we have available at the same per-mag price and no additional shipping charges. For reliable performance, there are only two names in magazines for 5900 series Smith & Wesson Pistols. One is Check-Mate, S&W’s own proprietary contractor. The other name is Mec-Gar. Mec Gar magazines ensure reliable functioning of semi-auto handguns in all manner of conditions, and they are the primary supplier for no less notables than Browning, Beretta, Sig Arms, and Smith & Wesson. Mec Gar magazines lock the slide back like they’re supposed to, and free-fall eject like they’re supposed to, every time. Here is Mec-Gar’s 10 round magazine for any Smith & Wesson 59 or 5900 type pistol, including models 59, 59-1, 659, 459, 669, 910, 915, 5903, 5906, 5946, 6906, and 6946. These magazines will also work very well in the Marlin Camp 9 Rifles, in Kel-Tec P11 pistols or SU-2000 rifles designed for Smith & Wesson magazines; and even in Star pistols models 28 and 30 but only Stars with their magazine safeties removed. The Smith & Wesson 459 and Star 30 in some of our photos are not included, and we are not advertising them for sale. These are solid blue steel bodied magazines with hard polymer black cartridge followers and extended spacer floorplate that ensures compliance in jurisdictions where standard magazines are restricted to Law Enforcement. Each magazine holds 10 rounds of 9mm caliber ammunition, five fewer than the standard 5915B Mec-Gar. If we are in stock on those, buyers residing in jurisdictions where those are permitted may sub at the same price. Please message us, though, and let us check stock if that is what you want to do. Our ME page gives a summary of the restrictive areas. Replacement pricing on factory S&W 5900 series magazines is upwards of $60 apiece. Our single magazine price on these Mec-Gars is $39 each. We’re offering the Mec Gar 10 round magazines, the Ones in the photo or their identical mates in lots of 3 or more at only $29 each. Own 3 $ 87.00. Not for sale to residents of New York City. Any magazine deliveries into New York City require written permission from the Police Commissioner, so we cannot ship magazines into any of the six boroughs or 176 some odd zip codes, per NYC Code 10-131.10.

Grips, Magazines, slings, holsters, scopes, mounts, parts & most any small light items, entire accessory orders only $10.00 total shipping no matter how many a person buys. $10.00 for an entire order, Not $10.00 per item or anything of the sort. $20 Flat Fee on magazine orders to Alaska, Hawaii, or Puerto Rico, and gun parts to PR civilians must ship to an FFL. title: For Sale:  COP 4 Barrel Derringer, .357 Magnum & .38 Special
postcontent:
COP
4 barrel Derringer
.357 Magnum Caliber

Weight	1.75 lb (0.8 kg) empty.
Length	5.6 inches (14.2 cm).
Width	1.062 inches (2.7 cm)
Height	4.1 inches (10.4 cm)

"As New Condition", patterned after the 1800's Remington Elliott Patent Derringer this Hand Cannon is a true and functional novelty, very few made in 1983.

The COP 357 is a 4 shot Derringer type pistol chambered for the powerful .357 Magnum round. It was designed by Robert Hillberg, based on his earlier work on the Hillberg Insurgency Weapon. It was manufactured by the now defunct COP Inc. of 3040 West Lomita Blvd., Torrance, California (COP stood for Compact Off-Duty Police). The double action weapon is only slightly larger than the typical .25 automatic pistol, which made it a good choice for a defensive weapon or a police backup gun.

The COP 357 is quite robust in design and construction. It is made of solid stainless steel components. Cartridges are loaded into the four separate chambers by sliding a latch that "pops-up" the barrel for loading purposes, similar to top-break shotguns. Each of the four chambers has its own dedicated firing pin. It uses an internal hammer, which is activated by depressing the trigger to hit a ratcheting/rotating striker that in turn strikes one firing pin at a time. Older "pepperboxes" also used multiple barrels, but the barrels were the part that rotated. The COP 357 operates similarly to the Sharps & Elliott rimfire pepperboxs of the 1850s, in that it uses the ratcheting/rotating striker, which is completely internal, to fire each chamber in sequence. If you live in Connecticut and have a Pistol Permit we can transfer just buy filling out the proper forms from DPS and calling into DPS for transfer number.  All others will have to go through yours and mine gun dealer.  I do not have the box it had come in.

The RFB is a short-stroke gas piston operated semi-automatic rifle in 7.62 mm NATO caliber. It accepts standard metric FAL type magazines which work "drop free" and do not need to be tilted in. title: For Sale:  Star model B 9mm Pistol Factory 9 Shot Magazine 1940s WWII Era Production 2 Piece Catch Slotted Grip Frame Excellent Condition
location: TN 90 mi East of Memphis, Memphis, Tennessee
postcontent:
Our # XM1298550

NO NYC. This listing is for ONE magazine; winning buyer, however, may take any number of extras we have on hand at the same per-mag price with no additional shipping charges. The shaky Spanish Economy is well publicized. As a direct result of that, here is a discovery from the reserve stock rooms of the Spanish Guardia of only a couple hundred factory Star Magazines to fit the legendary Star model B series pistols. These magazines are original Star production, and many of them are so marked on their floor plates. Manufacturer is the now defunct Star Echeverria Company of Eibar, Spain. Construction is entirely blue steel, from the bottom of their double or two piece catch floor plates to their stepped steel cartridge followers. Each magazine holds 9 rounds of standard 9mm ammunition; 9mm Luger, 9mm Parabellum, 9x19, call it what you will, THE 9mm. These are manufactured for the Star Model B Pistols with slotted front grip frames like the grip frame showing in our photos from a 1953 Israeli Police issued model B. These will not fit non-slotted Model Bs, manufactured after around 1965 without modifying them by bending their floorplates. We have other magazines listed on this venue for the non-slotted B, BS, and Super B Star Pistols. This one ain’t it. These magazines are not easy to find, and this is a one-time deal. Photos show representatives from the same lot, and the buyer will receive a magazine from the exact same lot as the photo specimens. Surface detractions are minimal, only etchy toning here and there on some of the magazines surfaces, and occasionally Spanish Guardia 3 or 4 digit identification numerals. We rate all of them as Very Good, or even Excellent, finishwise. The Guardia Police Armorers wisely stored them in well-greased condition. Original period correct factory Star magazines for the slotted Star Bs are high and in short supply worldwide. Many sellers ask upwards of $75 apiece for them. We’re offering the 1940s Star B Factory magazine in the photos, or its substantially identical mates from the same lot each for only $ 49.00. Not for sale to residents of New York City. Any magazine deliveries into New York City require written permission of the Police Commissioner, so we cannot ship magazines into New York City, per NYC Code 10-131.10.


Grips, Magazines, slings, holsters, scopes, mounts, parts & most any small light items,  entire accessory orders only $10.00 USPS Priority Mail with Adult Signature, total shipping no matter how many a person buys. A responsible adult will have to sign for the package! $10.00for an entire order, Not $10.00 per item or anything of the sort. $20 Flat Fee on magazine orders to Alaska, Hawaii, or Puerto Rico. MC/Visa/Discover/USPS MO paid orders shipped ASAP. Internet phone hours 8:30 – 4:30 CST Mon – Fri. Robertson Trading Post 117 Front Street PO Box 365 Henderson, Tennessee 38340. 	We buy, sell, and trade. Always have, since 1952.

title: For Sale:  AR-15 Stag Arms, SOTA Arms, with Magpul, BCM, GG&G, and NC Star extras
postcontent: Lower is a Stag Arms model Stag-15. Upper is a SOTA Arms, a smaller company out of Minnesota. They are still reputable though, and you can search them on the internet and read up on them if you wish.  The barrel is stamped NATO 5.56 1/9. The butt stock and grip are both Magpul in flat dark earth.  The charging handle is a BCM and larger than normal. The front and back sights at GG&G, and both are flip up and placed on angled attachments so as not to get in the way of the scope.  The scope is an NC Star 2-7x32 illuminated mil-dot reticle. It magnifies quite a bit, and illuminates in blue.  I don't remember what brand the foregrip is, but it doubles as a bipod and is also FDE in color.  The quad rail hand guard is from Acid Tactical  and is 7" in length, FDE in color. As you can see, there is plenty of room to add a flashlight or laser.  I will include one 30 rd pmag magazine, as pictured.  There have been zero rounds through this rifle. Being a vet, and used to the army issued M4, I thought I'd get more opportunities to shoot this thing, but that just hasn't happened.

postcontent:
Check out our website: http://nocohydrographics.jimdo.com/

I operate NOCO Hydrographics here in Fort Collins. If you're looking to get a firearm hydrodipped, I offer both the best prices as well as the best quality materials. I know how important quality is when it comes to any firearm work, and that's why I strive to be the best in the business. When you bring me one of your firearms, you can rest assured that the job will be done right, and come out looking great. After the pattern is applied, the part is coated with a high-strength clear coat with an internal flex agent. This means that the clear will flex without cracking when the gun is fired, and will last through many years of use.

I have over 700 patterns available in categories such as:
Camouflage
Carbon Fiber
Wood Grain
Stone
Metal
and Designer

With the introduction of the P938, SIG SAUER now offers the ballistic advantage of the 9mm cartridge in a platform similar in size to the best-selling P238 pistol. A single-action-only trigger, coupled with full-size SIGLITE® Night Sights makes the P938 handle like a much larger pistol, yet is still easy to carry concealed.

With dimensions just slightly larger than its .380ACP counterpart, the P938 packs six plus one rounds of
9mm into an all-metal frame. The cocked-and-locked single-action trigger gives the P938 unmatched
accuracy in a pistol its size.

Fans of the 1911 will find the thumb safety, magazine release and slide stop lever in familiar places. An
ambidextrous safety makes the P938 easy for left- and right-handed shooters. An extended seven-round
magazine will be available separately.

The most compact 9mm in the SIG SAUER product line, the P938 will be available in five configurations.

Features a Nitron®-coated stainless steel slide over a dark hard anodized alloy frame. Hogue® Rosewood Grips round out this package.

title: For Sale:  Mossberg Factory Cruiser Grip 12 gauge Model 500 535 835 590 Black
location: TN 90 mi East of Memphis, Memphis, Tennessee
postcontent:
Our # GRMB95000 	

This listing is for One Factory Mossberg Cruiser Grip assembly and all its hardware; buyers, however, may take any number of extras we have on hand at the same per-stock price and with no additional shipping charges. The venerable Mossberg 500 Shotgun had been around a long, long time before Cruiser style pistol grips became fashionable in the 1970s. We still see some home made hillbilly cruiser grips, whittled out of the original hardwood stocks, come into our store with the stock bolt shining. Our more affluent owners wrap those with gray duct tape. For the past 25 years, we see lots of them with their hardwood forends intact. The buttstock is much easier to change than the forend, no real disassembly of the shotgun required. A person just gets a Phillips screwdriver, takes one of the butt pad screws loose, swivels the pad, and then goes into the buttstock with an extension socket wrench or even a long shanked big flat head screwdriver, takes the old stock off. Then, using the big Allen wrench shown and enclosed, along with the washers, install the pistol grip. Even our photographer can perform the procedure. Photos show brand new factory Cruiser grips we took off some Mossberg 500 M&P Parkerized finish 18 inch barreled shotguns, so we leave their conventional buttstocks on them. All these grips are brand new, factory fresh with their factory plastic bag and hardware like the one in the photos. Installation leaves an overall length of well over 28 inches. Installation will, however, transform the Shotgun into Any Other status on the 4473 form, and owners must be at least 21 years of age, same rules as handguns. Also, installation may run a person afoul of local laws, checking those is the responsibility of the buyer. Buyers should be advised that 12 gauge shotguns generate substantial recoil, and should be kept well away from the operator’s face while firing. These cruiser grips will fit any 12 gauge model 500, model 535, Model 590, or Model 835. They will not fit a Remington 870 or the gear shift column of a 1963 Pontiac. Replacement pricing on these often approaches $60 apiece in our area. We’re offering them each, however, the factory Mossberg grip in the photos or its identical mates, for only $ 29.00. 

Grips, Magazines, slings, holsters, scopes, mounts, parts & most any small light items, entire accessory orders only $10.00 total shipping no matter how many a person buys. $10.00 for an entire order, Not $10.00 per item or anything of the sort. $20 Flat Fee on magazine orders to Alaska, Hawaii, or Puerto Rico, and gun parts to PR civilians must ship to an FFL. Magazines and any small light non-gun items ride free with ammo orders. We accept checks with no more than 7 days hold. GA Pay, MC, Visa, Discover phone- or fax-in 7 3 1 9 8 9 4 7 2 3 orders, USPS Money Order items shipped ASAP please put your full information, venue number, and what the item is on any messages. Internet phone hours 8:00 – 5:00 CST Mon – Fri. Robertson Trading Post 117 Front Street PO Box 365 Henderson, Tennessee 38340. We buy, sell, and trade. Always have, since 1952.

location: TN 90 mi East of Memphis, Memphis, Tennessee
postcontent:
Our # GR61007

This listing is for One set of grips; buyers, however, may take as many extra sets as we have on hand at the same per-set price, and with no additional shipping charges. All Smith & Wesson J Frame Revolvers made since the mid 1990s are Round Butt Grip Frame, and Square Butt Js were never plentiful. Hogue grips have knocked Pachmayr off the ruling perch in the past 20 years with their ergonomics and affordability. Pachmayr, of course, wins all the beauty contests, but for shooting comfort and ease of handling, Hogue is the winner. This is Hogue's pink colored, finger grooved, compact size, concealable grip to fit any Smith & Wesson J Frame Revolver with round butt grip frame. Manufacturer is Hogue, Inc. of Paso Robles, CA. Construction is two piece pink outer shell rubberized polymer, with a hard black internal sleeve bonded to an absorbent yet firm synthetic rubber with stippled surfaces. Anchor inserts are steel, and they use the frame of the revolver itself for strength, not screw and escutcheon type that can easily loosen and break. These grips fit models 31, 33, 34, 35, 36, 37, 38 and any of their 6 prefix stainless variants, including the model 60 itself. Smith & Wesson small or J frame revolvers, most specimens made since about 1995 are round butt, includes models 34, 650, 651 and the 3 prefix Air Lite siblings. For any shoppers who aren’t clear whether you have a round or square butt revolver, please see the grip frame photo. Lord knows there are plenty of them out there and there will be for decades to come. We mean the round butt Smith & Wessons. These Hogue Bantams preserve the compactness and don’t really take up as much space as a traditional set of Magna Goncalo Grips with a Tyler T on them. We're offering these fine grips for only $24.00.



Grips, Magazines, slings, holsters, scopes, mounts, parts & most any small light items, entire accessory orders only $10.00 total shipping no matter how many a person buys. $10.00 for an entire order, Not $10.00 per item or anything of the sort. $20 Flat Fee on magazine orders to Alaska, Hawaii, or Puerto Rico, and gun parts to PR civilians must ship to an FFL. Magazines and any small light non-gun items ride free with ammo orders. We accept checks with no more than 7 days hold. title: For Sale/Trade:  duracoated custom AR-15 PRICE RECUCED!
postcontent:
I have a high quality AR-15 build that is priced to sell.    I had a handguard that I took off a rock river predator that I refinished, and coated with duracoat matte satin.  It turned out really nice, so I used it on this build.  While i was at it, I duracoated the barrel.  This is a 223 wylde chambered (tighter tolerance makes it more accurate than a standard 5.56 while still maintaining the functional reliability) The upper and lower receivers are anderson manufacturing, with a ptac milspec lower build kit and collapsible stock.  The bolt/carrier group is a full auto, so it will last next to forever, and also nice because they are built a little more robust and have the correct mass for cycling properly.   Gas tube is stainless, low profile gas steel gas block (not aluminum).  When refinishing the handguard, I cut holes on the underside to  easily access the gas block.  Also doubles as a sling stud hole. If you ever want to change to a quad rail, these easy access holes will come in really handy.  Milspec charging handle, and 30 rd steel magazine.

Bipod is not included unless you want to buy it extra, the gun has had 2 rounds fired through it to ensure a good primer strike and proper ejection angle.

Early 20th Century pre-model 10. These were manufactured between 1915 - 1942.  I am not a S&W historian though and  make no warrantable claim on its age.

title: For Sale:  Remington 700 .223 26" Varmint Heavy Barrel
postcontent:
I purchased this rifle new myself and added the Leupold Vari XIII scope. The scope power is adjustable from 3.5-10X and the objective diameter is 50mm. The lenses are perfect with not even a fingerprint. The optics are beautiful and crisp. The condition of the rifle is mint. No scratches that I can find on the laminate wood stock either. The laminate wood stock has nice checkering on the grip and forearm, a rubber butt pad, and a raised cheekrest. The heavy varmint barrel length is 26 inches. Capacity is 5 rounds plus 1 in the chamber. This rifle easily shoots 3/4" groups with quality ammunition. This rifle comes with a two piece steel Leupold base, two steel Leupold rings, Butler Creek flip up scope caps, and original paperwork. I have the mount and ring boxes as well as the original Remington receiver screws. I have fired this less than 100 rounds, have taken maybe a dozen ground hogs, but it has spent most of its life in the safe. I'm selling only to fund another purchase. 

I'm willing to possibly use as a partial trade on a Kriss .45 ACP carbine, and willing to pay extra in cash if you want to trade one for my Remington.

I will sell the rifle seperate from the scope, mount, caps, and rings for $650.00. For the Leupold scope, rings, caps, and mount, I am asking $425.00. For the whole package, I am asking $1000.00. You can keep the sales tax! Shipping is available for a marginal amount. Face to face transaction is possible.

This rifle is for sale in Rockfield, located in Carroll County.

title: For Sale:  Modified 3rd Generation Glock 23
postcontent:
For sale is a 3rd Generation Glock 23.
This firearm has not been fired since all upgrades were done.
The exterior is flawless.

Below is a list of upgrades installed.
Stainless steel Lone wolf barrel which is ported and extends 1 inch out of the slide.
3.5 pound ultimate Ghost rocket connector, which was then polished, tuned, and fitted. This connector is part of the process to eliminate over travel and will also give you a faster reset.
The trigger and trigger bar was then modified, tuned, and polished as well.
A new trigger housing with an adjustable over travel stop was installed.
The factory firing pin and safety plunger was deburred and then polished.
All competition Wolff springs were also installed.
A DPM recoil system was also installed.
Lone wolf grip plug(punisher skull design)
Also had a stainless steel upgrade which consist of the external slide locking lever, slide release, and 3 pins.

The trigger feels amazing and you will not be disappointed.

I purchased the firearm from a buddy of mine, which he only shot 50 rounds through. Since everything was installed I haven't shot it once.
All parts pretty much have no miles on them.
The sale will include original box.
All factory parts removed.
Original barrel.
A stainless steel 9mm barrel and a magazine for 9mm.
Along with 2 beaver tails.

Custom shop gun. I'm the original owner and it is in very fine condition. There is NO play between the frame and slide; side to side or up and down...it is an incredible fit. I've shot many 1911 pistols...this is the smoothest shooting (feeling) one I have ever shot -that might sound weird but if you've ever shot really fine 1911's you know what I'm talking about. For sale is a good condition Colt Combat Government Model slide with Colt National Match .45 ACP barrel and collet style bushing. This is a Series 70 slide as it doesn't have the firing pin safety. Finish is very good but there is some thinning on the edges and a couple of dings on the front sight and muzzle end of the slide. Nothing a fine file/hard backed sand paper and a re-blue won't fix. I believe the barrel to be original. The Combat Government was a limited production model of the standard Govt Model that included factory high profile sights, lowered and flared ejection port, and upgraded barrel among other refinements on the frame. This slide comes with new Ed Brown firing pin, spring, and stop.  A great way to start that custom 1911 build you've always wanted.

title: For Sale:  BNIB Shiloh Sharps 40-65 "Montana Roughrider" RARE & HARD TO FIND
postcontent:
Frank Mayer born in 1850 was an old time buffalo hunter in the days when Bill Hickok, Buffalo Bill, and such made their footprints in the sands of history. He may also have been the oldest living Civil War veteran at the time as he lied about his age in 1863 and became a drummer boy in the Union Army. For four years from 1872 through 1875, Mayer hunted buffalo and was the last surviving "buffalo runner" as he called it.

Mayer started hunting in Texas and moved North with the herds. His rifles were Sharps. First came the .40-70 and the .40-90. Then Mayer got his big rifle, a sixteen pound .45 that shot a 550 grain bullet. The Sharps rifle goes all the way back to a time two years before Frank Mayer was born. Christian Sharps received his patent in 1848 for a sliding breech action on a percussion rifle. Unlike most muzzle loaders in use at the time that required powder be poured down the barrel from the muzzle end and then the bullet seated and rammed home, Sharps' rifle had a lever activated breech block that opened downward. A linen or paper cartridge consisting of a bullet and proper powder charge was inserted and the closing of the breech block tore the paper exposing the powder. Instead of a single percussion cap, the Sharps rifle first used a circular capper and then a roll of caps not unlike cap guns used in the early days.

The Sharps was used in the Civil War and a trained shooter could get off ten shots in one minute with the Sharps mechanism and design. The first 9,000 Sharps rifles of 1859 went to the military, and the famous Berdan Sharpshooters were armed with .52 caliber Sharps rifles. In all the Union purchased over 80,000 Sharps rifles.

It was an easy step for the Sharps from the use of linen or paper cartridges to the new fixed ammunition. By 1869 Christian Sharps was long gone from the company and Richard Lawrence received a patent that year for a new rifle and started designing and chambering large brass cartridges for what would soon become the Model of 1874. By 1881 the Sharps Rifle Company, like the buffalo, was gone. You won't find agreement on what chamberings were found in the Sharps as we have already pointed out. Some well known chamberings were .40-70, .40-90, .44-77, .45-110, .50-70, and the Big Fifty, the .50-90.

Sharps rifles were generally blued steel with case hardened receiver and butt plate, and a straight grip walnut stock. Barrel lengths were normally from 22" to 32" and octagon in shape. In the 1870's Frank Mayer's Sharps rifle, complete with bullet mold and reloading dies, cost $225 with an extra charge of $80 for the scope, at a time when a buffalo skinner averaged $38.50 a week. Sorta puts the cost of a modern Sharps in perspective doesn't it?

The original Sharps Rifle Company may be gone but the void has been filled in modern times by the Shiloh Rifle Manufacturing Company of Big Timber Montana. The "new" Sharps company goes back to 1976, opening operation 95 years after the demise of the original company. Known as Shiloh Products, there would be a split in 1983 with two companies emerging, Shiloh and C. Sharps.

One does not simply go to a local dealer and pick and choose from a rack of Sharps rifles. In fact there is a L-O-N-G back order situation. Many folks have hesitated ordering one when the delay was one year. Then the back order for one reached two years, eventually the wait for one of these fine pieces of history was four years!

YOU CAN OWN ONE OF THESE EXCLUSIVE "Montana Roughrider" RIFLES RIGHT NOW AT THIS VERY MOMENT!

Shiloh Rifle Manufacturing states: 

"As with the original Sharps, our rifles are not intended for the mass market. They are for the shooter, hunter, and competitor who wants something special. 

Therefore we will never sacrifice quality for higher production figures. To do so would compromise the soul of this product, and disappoint those wishing today for the quality that was the norm in 19th Century American firearms.

"We feel that Shiloh rifles reflect the extra time and effort that go into their manufacture. Due to the tremendous shooter acceptance of the Shiloh Sharps we find ourselves in a lengthy back-order situation. We wish to assure potential Shiloh Sharps customers that by increasing our work force and by turning to state-of-the art machinery, we are striving to reduce that waiting period." 

NO WAITING PERIOD at High Country Guns & Ammo as you can own yours TODAY!

***NOTE: Shiloh Rifles come in a variety of styles and calibers. They also come with the recommendation that smokeless powder handloads not be used in the large volume black powder cartridge of the 1870's. The Shiloh is built like the Sharps was in 1874 and should be used the same way.

Chamberings available include .38-55, .40-50, .40-65, .40-70, .40-90, .44-77, .44-90, .45-70, .45-90, .45-100, .45-110, .45-120, .50-70, and .50-90. In all of these the first number represents the caliber while the second is the charge of black powder in the original cartridge. 

High Country Guns & Ammo is PROUD to present a BRAND NEW, NEVER FIRED Sharps Shiloh "Montana Roughrider Rifle" 40-65, 30" half octagon barrel with a weight of 9 1/2 lbs. for the LOW PRICE of $2899.99. And believe us, THAT is a LOW PRICE for this BNIB replicated piece of history. Equipped with Baldwin Front Sights as well as additional extras, you will not find one at a better price, AND WITH NO WAITING PERIOD.

If you go to: http://www.shilohrifle.com/rifles.php

The 1874 Montana Roughrider STARTS AT $1959.00 to begin building a "stripped" down version, once you begin customizing with such items as:

Standard grade wood (shown with Semi-fancy)
Shotgun or Military Buttstock
No Cheek Rest
Pistol Grip
Double Set Triggers
Your choice of barrel length and weight
Buckhorn Rear Sight: Full or Semi
Blade Front Sight

The price EASILY begins to extend up into the stratosphere in price.

Price: $2899.99 + Applicable Taxes

Please make any inquires regarding this offering by calling High Country Guns & Ammo where one of our associates will be glad to assist you with any questions you may have at: REDACTED.

Customer service and satisfaction is our main goal at High Country, should you be interested in a different offering, we carry a substantial variety of different models and manufacturers from Glock to Sig Sauer (as well as many different rifle combinations from AR-15's to the Ruger 10/22).

Thank you for viewing, and have a nice day.

The High Country Team 


***Trivia: Shiloh is now located in Big Timber, Montana. The company produced the legendary 1874 Sharps Rifle, featured in the 1990 Western film Quigley Down Under, starring Tom Selleck.
